title.narrative: Strengthening Education and Agri-business interaction for sustained employment and agricultural Development in South Africa

description.narrative:
**This project aims for the following objectives and long-term impact**
- Contribute to End hunger (SDG 2) - End poverty in all forms (SDG 1)
**Long-term impact**
- Promote agricultural growth - Create ecologically sustainable food systems - Reduce malnutrition
**Medium-term impact is defined as follows**(I) Education system (TVET/HE) is of good quality, relevant and accessible (SDG 4); (II) Partnerships between persons and organisations are inclusive and sustainable (SDG 17); (III) Organisations key to (sectoral) inclusive development of partner countries are strengthened by inflow of enhanced workforce.1) TVET/HE organisations in South Africa and the Netherlands improve core task performance, firmly embedded in their environment, and in line with national, provincial and sector specific labour market needs, whilst aiming at inclusiveness.**Output(s)**1.1 Establishment of a learning network of industry, education, NGOs and government agencies, based on a sustainable business model and effective in maximising the mutually beneficial relationships between agricultural education and the agricultural industries1.2 Mainstreaming of gender interests and interests of previously disadvantaged groups in all jointly developed approaches and products1.3 Consolidated institutional collaboration between “green” education institutes in RSA and the Netherlands1.4 Approaches based on education-industry collaboration for the best practice delivery of trade qualifications at all levels are firmly embedded in the strategies of participating organisations1.5 Sustained investments in four Education Agri-parks/networks1.6 Curricula of the participating educational institutes are jointly reviewed and adapted for inclusion of quality practical experience/internship programmes – and implemented - in cooperation with the industry, famers and other relevant stakeholders.1.7 Strengthened staff capacity of the participating educational institutes ,translating labour market demand into curriculum design, delivery and management

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: Project photo
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

title.narrative: A. TVET/HE organisations perform better their core tasks, firmly embedded in their environment
A.E.5. Number of curricula for degree, non-degree and short courses revised/newly developed

description.narrative: Degree: bachelor's, master's and doctorate Non degree: Certificate and diploma

comment.narrative: 16-03-2021: For all 4 sectors we have reviewed the curricula and formulated gaps. Next to that we had meetings with indurstry about the needs and skills requirements for graduates. Both initiatives helped to make a strategy for curricula and education program improvements. This revise of curricula is an ongoing proces. Now all networks and relations with industry are "renewed" the organisations are building a strategy to review and update the curricula yearly. | 16-03-2021: In this project we focus on 4 sectors. Dairy, Poultry and Pig production and Horticulture production. For that we have made focus on the curricula in Animal and Plant science. We have approved the practical demand and possibilities for more specialised placements.

25-08-2021: In the first project year the project focused on 8 curricula for education related to Pig production, Poultry production, Dairy production and Horti culture and related curricula. We found out that all important Job related requirements are captured in the curricula, the roll out however was more theory focused. For that, in the second year we focused on short courses in 1. Leading study groups (as facilitators), and design short courses in Broilers, Free range chicken, Pigs and cattle/ goats production this work is in development stage. 2. Working with other and online didactics (Blended learning), transfer to coach! 3. Including SDG’s by training lecturers in integration of Safe future food systems in excisting curricula.

title.narrative: A.O.6. Number of facilities established/strengthened

comment.narrative: 16-03-2021: At Stellenbosch University we have invested in AGRO HUB. This is a classroom specially designed for Blended Learning activities. This classroom is situated at Stellenbosch University, between business incubators,

30-08-2021: In the first project year the project has supported Stellenbosch university with investment for a integrated business Online learning classroom. For Elangeni TVET plans are under development to invest in the school farm together with related industry. The idea is to upgrade the facilities for Pig producton, a broiler unit and small investment horticulture hydroponics system, these investments supporting education and studygroup sessions with emerging farmers next to extend network activities with industry.

title.narrative: A.E.7. Student satisfaction

comment.narrative: 16-03-2021: At this moment it is to early to measure student satisfaction.

title.narrative: A.R.2. Number of relevant publications (level, gender, inclusion)

comment.narrative: 16-03-2021: At this moment there are no publications designed and distributed.

25-08-2021: Elangeni TVET College Newsletter has covered Nobuhle Dimba, Vamokuhle Nzimande and the Nuffic planning meeting at Mpumalanga campus. Nobuhle Dimba is growing her own vegetables. Vamokuhle Nzimande is keeping and selling chickens and eggs.

title.narrative: A.E.4. Number of graduates delivered

comment.narrative: 16-03-2021: Because this project has only been in operation for one year, We can't measure the student graduates clearly. We are sure in the end of 2021 we can have a better estimation of student graduates with enriched comepetences. Looking at teachers, 20 teachers are trained and more or less graduated for the skills training. Next step is to train them as trainer for emerging farmers. At this point we did not yet train emerging farmers, so there is no result on gradutes in this target group. Although many processes in South Africa, including education, has been put on halt now due to COVID-19, we hope we can catch up all activities soon, to be able to continue with deliverance of graduates on all levels.

title.narrative: A.O.4. Number of organisations with a revised/developed system to registrate and monitor its alumni

comment.narrative: 16-03-2021: Both organisations are working on improving their alumni tracing system. Elangeni is in the process of developing a client survey index for follow up with prospective and actual employers of students and alumni. University of Stellenbosch conducts annual surveys to graduates and employers.
30-08-2021: Elangeni TVEt is currently reviving its alumni structure across all programmes of the college and this will include former students of Primary agriculture and of Farming.

title.narrative: A.O.11. Number of organisations with policies and procedures to ensure an environment which is gender sensitive

comment.narrative: 16-03-2021: Both project partners are gender sensitive and have active policy to ensure the environment is gender sensitive.All education organisations need to follow up National policies for gender. In those policies there are also requirements for the gender sensitive environments.

title.narrative: A.E.1. Number of (knowledge) institutions supported directly

comment.narrative: 16-03-2021: During training activities and strategic meetings about curriculum construction and improvement, institutions near to the country A partners were involved in all sessions. Interesting to see is that all organisations profit of the discussions and steps we made. Also in actions that are formulated during workshops, all other organsiations were invilved or want to be involved. Compliments here for Elangeni and Stellenbosch university who spend time in a network development approach in stead of own organisation centered approach. These organisations perform better: KZN: near to Elangeni 5 other TVET's: Umfofolozi, Costal, Mthashana, Majuba, Esayidie and to HE organisations: Cedara and University of Kwazulu Natal (UKZN) WC: near to Stellenbosch,Villa Academy, Elzenburg and Koudebokkenveld are involved

title.narrative: A.S.4. Number of SMEs supported

comment.narrative: 16-03-2021: Elangeni TVET: Estimated 150 farmers reached via: Business Breakfast, Gender Forums, Motivation Workshops, Articulation HE Conference, Farmers Exhibitions and farm visits. Stellenbosch University: Koue Bokkeveld trains 8000 farmers and entrepreneurs a year with e-learning short courses as well as courses at NQF 3&4 level. Stellenbosch is exploring whether an NQF 5 course can be developed.
25-08-2021: In KZN Elangeni region Nobuhle Dimba, Vamokuhle, Mthobisi and Lindokuhle are supported.

title.narrative: A.O.8. % of women of teaching staff of faculty/department

comment.narrative: 16-03-2021: Elangeni has 50% Female Blac teaching staff in the Agriculture department Stellenbosch has 48% Female teaching staff in the Agriculture department.

title.narrative: A.O.9. Number of organisations with improved policies or procedures to encourage access to education of minorities

comment.narrative: 16-03-2021: In South Africa all colleges need to work with a national policy on access for minorities. So all institutes will have policies and improved policies for access of minorities. The both country A partners try to involve other TVET / HE organizations. So that all actions and trainings have as much as possible impact. The improved policies or procedures are shared. Like the teacher skill training. staff from other TVET organizations are invited to join the training. For all other issues, each time other institutes are invited to join in meetings and budget is shared to finally have more alumni.

title.narrative: A.O.12. Number of organisations with policies and procedures to ensure an environment which is conducive for minorities

comment.narrative:
16-03-2021: In South Africa and globally, the emphasis is increasingly on building inclusive societies where diversity, in all its manifestations, is valued and harnessed as key to society's development and well-being. South Africa's higher education system reflects this diversity and acknowledges the need to transform (Higher Education Act 101 of 1997; Education White Paper 3: A Programme for Higher Education Transformation [1997a]; Education White Paper 6: Special Needs Education; Building an inclusive education and training system [2001]; National Plan for Higher Education of 2000; Strategic Policy Framework on Disability for the Post-School Education and Training System [2018]). SU is no exception with its increasingly diverse student body and staff corps that embody not only South Africa’s strengthening democracy, but also broader global trends, such as the increasing inclusion of people with disabilities in higher education. The Constitution of South Africa (RSA, 1996) and the country’s legislative framework create an enabling environment to foster respect for diversity and to protect people from discrimination based on race, gender and disability. These principles also feature strongly in the policy governing the higher education system, which emphasises the imperative that all members of society participate equitably in, and benefit from, higher education, with specific reference to people with disabilities in higher education. 1.2 In line with these developments in society in the broader sense and as a means to strive towards social justice, SU has increasingly sought to assert the importance of these values to its strategic vision and its role as a university in South Africa and greater Africa.
Elangeni TVET aligns its activities with students with special education needs tot he DHET SSS framework document and the DHET Strategic policy framework on disability fort he post school education and training system. To develop our student support plan prio ...

title.narrative: A.S.3. Number of students performing an internship or practical work

comment.narrative: 16-03-2021: In the first worksjop meetings it became clear that especially TVET organisations have problems with finding internship places and practical work possibilities. Through meetings with industry and education, organized in this SEAD SA project, network linkages have been established. Elangeni TVET organised a Business breakfast for sector related industry. From this meeting new placements for students have been offered. Stellenbosch University has no problems for practial work and Internships. The connection with industry on Horticulture sector is good and for that placements are good to organize.

title.narrative: A.E.2. Increased participation of students from minorities

comment.narrative: 16-03-2021: In this project our partners are a TVET with students who are only from previously disadvantaged backgrounds, which means mainly black communities. At Stellenbosch it is quite different, here there are those from priviledged backgrounds as well as about ¼ from previously disadvantaged backgrounds . So what is a minority? In the TVET a white rich student is a minority. In Stellenbosch University there is policy for more participation of students from black communities. Because Elangeni is country A partner in this project we have a direct inclusion of students from previously disadvantaged communities (black). Many students are from poor households. Because the focus in KZN is on 3 sectors poultry, dairy and pig production, we influence the animal husbandry programs. In this program many students participate. At this stage we envisage to educate 2 groups (classes). The number will be higher towards the end of the project, because we focus on teacher capacity and curriculum improvement.

title.narrative: A.E.3. Number of staff that have gained qualitative and relevant knowledge and skills to develop and offer the revised/developed study programmes

comment.narrative: 16-03-2021: In total we have trained 20 staff practical skills in the different sectors. 5 Staff are involved as program managers or farm managers, they have been trained likewise.10 Teaching staff was involved in curricula review and gap formulation. In October 2019 representatives from all education institutes have followed a class about integration of future food systems. For 2020 we had foreseen more training and also training in the development of study programs, we hope to pick up on this after COVID-19.

title.narrative: A.O.5. Number of organisations that have developed and implemented a system to regularly survey the satisfaction of students, short courses participants, graduates and/or employers

comment.narrative: 16-03-2021: Stellenbosch University and Elangeni will arrange a survey after graduation in December (Assuming COVID-19 does not delay this too much).

30-08-2021: Elsenburg, Kou Bokkeveld, Northern Cape TVET, KromCo, Boland College in Western Cape region have implemented a survey system for student satisfactory. We have agreed to share the approaches in Q3 and Q$ with Elangeni in a project meeting.

title.narrative: A.E.6. Number of students enrolled in revised/newly developed study programmes

comment.narrative:
16-03-2021: The goal of this project is to increase skills and knowledge in 4 sectors at two institutes. Because we will not design new curricula, but instead "upgrade" the existing curricula, we think that many students in the excising flows will benefit from this work. Easy to identify at this moment: 1. We have been training teaching staff. So after the training, current students are profiting from better skilled teachers 2. The new placements/ internships are not only open to new students but also for current students
In addition to improving curricula we are supporting Blended Learning in all 4 sectors. Blended Learning has two advantages: 1. Existing students can specialize more easily by combining standard education with online specialization in dairy, poultry, pig production or Horti. 2. For non students there is an open gateway to enter high quality sector education at the TVET or University of Stellenbosch

title.narrative: A.O.7. % of women in management of faculty/department

comment.narrative: 16-03-2021: These are the figures from one coutnry A partner, Elangeni. Stellenbosch has 26% female in management functions.

title.narrative: A.O.3. Number of organisations revised/developed institutional mechanism for quality assurance

comment.narrative: 16-03-2021: This is not part of the project.
30-08-2021: This indicator is not applicable related to our project focus.

title.narrative: A.O.2. Number of organisations revised/developed and implemented a strategic plan

comment.narrative: 16-03-2021: This number of organisations are involved in the project rol out. In that rol out the strategy for education in the 4 sectors are developed next to other relevant strategies concerning Gender and Inclusion. This influences the planning for: 1. Network activities 2. HR development 3. Placement of students 4. Gender policies At this moment all is under development and we plan to implement new approaches during summer 2020. Due nto COVID -19 we need to move that to 2021.

30-08-2021: During the second project year we have integrated a strategic plan for curricula improvement and knowledge transfer: 1. Safe Future food systems: (5) organization have been trained to integrate these systems in daily education 2. Knowledge transfer in study groups for emerging Farmers. In this strategy the agro industry is included. So network development. (3) 3. Blended Learning, the introduction of Blended Learning skills (4). These didactics help to make students more active with knowledge and in that way more time is left for individual competency development related to job related skills, soft skills and responsibility for individual learning processes. 4. Krom Co and Elzenburg TVET (2) in process of establishing formal legal partnership.

title.narrative: A.R.1. Number of research strategies/agenda/methodologies revised/strengthened and implemented

comment.narrative: 16-03-2021: This project is focussing on TVET level/ education and practical sector apporach. Research is not mentioned in the log frame. So we have not a prior focus on research strategies.
25-08-2021: This is not a target indicator in our project

title.narrative: A.R.3. Number of relevant innovations

comment.narrative: 16-03-2021: We are designing 4 pathways for Blended Learning for the four sectors. Basic online material has been produced in The NLs by education and industry. We are contextualizing this material and translating it into English so that it can be used by the partner institutes. We aim to pilot this innovative knowledge support in the second part of 2020. See the attachment for a first impression.

25-08-2021: We have introduced the following innovations: 1. Focus on Blended Learning: We have designed and integrated 2 trainings in Blended learning. Focussing on the didactical things and use of online material. This didactic will bring learners in the lead in practice. 2. Development of a safe food for the future approach in existing curricula 3. Design of studygroups to share knowledge as TVET with emerging farmers. In that process we transferred teachers from lecturers into learning facilitator. This is also an important enrichment for the day to day education. Since industry and NGO’s are involved in these studygroups. 4. A partnership with Umngeni water is at emerging stage. The plan collaborate with Umgeni Water and their partners in the following areas: • Water friendly farming methods;• Water harvesting methods to include in the Curriculum for a bridging qualification;• Improving water systems;• Soil fertility• Types of irrigation systems;• Water use efficiency;• Systems of sustainable farming;• Waste water systems; • Catchment area management;• Women and youth development;• Assistance on equipment donation, and other funding;• Emerging farmer development via college lecturer development; Work intergrated learning for students of Elangeni in the areas related to water • Possible assistance on Master’s program through the Umgeni Water Scientific Services Unit; and• Exploration of borehole project initiatives.

title.narrative: A.S.1. Number of beneficiaries in the society reached with knowledge, skills and techniques

comment.narrative:
16-03-2021: We foresee two actions that can support the outreach: 1. Student intervention teams. As part of the long-term relationship between SA and NL education we are planning to set up student intervention teams (students form SA and NL in mixed teams). These teams will: - Conduct a survey in the field among SME's and Emerging farmers - Based on the responses received students will develop in small teams specific knowledge products such as for instance user-friendly leaflets, apps etc. - From this survey we also identify the need for farming skills and specific skills training. This will be organised and carried out at the colleges.
2. The second action is Smartg use of Blended Learning materials. With online materials we are planning to reach out with knowledge (clips) to the society via mobile phones.

25-08-2021: At Elangeni in this stage 22 Emerging Farmers are trained and received important skills and knowledge via the study group activity. The planning is to train in total 130 emerging farmers starting from here. At Stellenbosch the Future Food system training has 10 attendees. Each attendee will train with this new gained knowledge 35 extra other people. In total 350 persons.

title.narrative: A.S.2. Number of MoUs or other types of collaboration agreements signed (education, private, public, surrounding community)

comment.narrative: 16-03-2021: We have 10 MOU's - we call them Letters of Intent (LoI). Please see the attached file. The industry has been active with bringing in Innovations in teacher training. (picture). In KZN, in total 6 TVET colleges might joined that can bring in teachers for training and we are busy with signing more LOI's with them. Stellenbosch University is entering into agreements with with Villa Academy, Koue Bokkeveld and AgriColleges. LoI are being finalised.
25-08-2021: The project is supported by many organizations who have signed a LOI (Letter of Intent) during tender phase or after the inception phase.

title.narrative: A.S.5. Number of improvements in (inter)national policies/laws

comment.narrative:
16-03-2021: We organized a high level meeting at the embassy in Pretoria. This meeting was scheduled the 14th of April 2020. (and did not find place because of COVID-19).With the input from meetings (sept. 2019) with stakeholders from education and industry we constructed a "Concept note". This concept note is the basis for this meeting with DHET and DAFF. We want to discuss the upograde of AEC's and next to that supporting budget for TVET's to be able to send students for skill training weeks in these AEC's. We aim for a pilot, to show and evaluate the strenght of skill training towards better professionalisation in the 4 sectors.
Both organisations are active in regional and national policy and law groups. Sometimes on sector level, sometimes on social level. So the interaction and professional input is appreciated also on htah level.
30-08-2021: Not applicable in our project

FNS.3 Create ecologically sustainable food systems
FNS.3.1. Number of hectares of farmland used more eco-friendly

comment.narrative: 16-03-2021: A survey is planned to be undertaken in November 2020 as part of the Sustainable Agriculture WIL module at University of Stellenbosch. Dutch intern students will assist in case studies to quantify the changes.
30-08-2021: In Western Cape 80 farmers trained an implementing climate sensitive agriculture,at Kouw Bokkeveld, each with min of 10 ha farm

title.narrative: FNS.3.2. Number of hectares of farmland that become part of improved watershed/landschape management

comment.narrative: 30-08-2021: Not applicabl;e for this project.

title.narrative: FNS.3.3. Number of hectares of farmland that agro-ecologically became more resilient to shocks
FNS.2 Promote agricultural growth
FNS.2.1. Number of family farms (sub-sector, male/female, age: % < 35) with increased productivity and/or income

comment.narrative:
16-03-2021: Through Elangeni the strategic plan is to improve teaching skills for the 4 selected sectors. Through coopeartion with industry and Agricultural training centers where each sector is united. In these AEC's skill training and innovations are brought together for students, teachers and emerging farmers. In that way teachers can also train farmers on these AEC's where equipment and animals are relevant for training.
SU: currently work with larger scale family farms but these are all white owned. It will not be possible to change them black owned. However, we will aim for female supervisors to be realised (source, NPC 2016). Supervisors will be reached through the employers survey which will be designed as part of project. This survey we will have to do electronically in 2020.
Because we are still in the "construction" phase of building teh network, upgrade teacher skills, identify learning strategies, we did not train farmers yet.

30-08-2021: The project is badly influenced by COVID-19. Initially we planned to support 140 emerging farmers. With the introduction of a study group approach we think we can reach out to 100-140 emerging farmers in 2021. Next to that we will introduce a Blended Learning platform for dairy production, this will be piloted via Future Farmers and in that way in bigger Dairy production farms. So in total we think we manage to support 150 farms directly to improve productivity. The systematic approach will lead to more knowledge and skills transfer, since studygroup approach and use of blended learning platforms will be integrated so it is to be expected that more farms will benefit in the long term. At this moment we expect in the 22 emerging farms increased productivity. 15 of the 22 are younger than 35 years old.

B.I.6. Number of stimulating measures/extra facilities aimed at preparation, supervision and aftercare of female candidates
B.I.7. Number of stimulating measures/extra facilities aimed at preparation, supervision and aftercare of minorities
B.I.8. % alumni / TMT participants who state that they have acquired new knowledge and skills; e.g. problem solving, effective communication
B.I.9. % alumni / TMT participants who are promoted to a more strategic position post-study
B.O.1. Number of organisations strengthened by individual and/or group training
B.O.2. % of alumni / TMT participants who have applied the acquired knowledge and skills within their working environment
B.O.3. Number of organisations with institutional mechanism for quality assurance
B.O.4. Number of organisations developed and implemented a gender strategy
FNS.1 Reduce malnutrition
FNS.1.1. Number of undernourished people with improved food intake
FNS.1.2. Number of undernourished people with improved access to healthy/diverse food
FNS.1.3. Number of undernourished people whose nutritional situation became more resilient to shocks
SRHR.1 Better information and greater freedom of choice for young people about their sexuality
SRHR.1.2. Number of young people reached with comprehensive, correct information on sexuality, HIV/AIDS, STIs, pregnancy and contraception
SRHR.1.3. Number of health facilities that adopt and implement youth-friendly SRHR and HIV/AIDS services
SRHR.1.4. % of women (20-24yr) who were married or in union before ages 15 and 18
SRHR.1.5. % of girls and women (15-49yr) who have undergone FGM/C
SRHR.1.6. Condom use by young people at last high-risk sex
SRHR1.1. Number of youth who participate in policy and decision-making bodies and perceive their participation as meaningful
SRHR.2 Improved access to contraceptives and medicines
SRHR.2.1. Total Dutch ODA for R&D for essential SRH and HIV/AIDS medicines, vaccines and commodities
SRHR.2.2. Number of and type of new user-friendly SRH products on the market
SRHR.2.3. Number of children fully immunized
SRHR.2.4. Number of additional women and girls using modern contraceptives
SRHR.2.5. Number of couples protected by various contraceptives over a 1-year period (couple-years protection)
SRHR.2.6. Number of and % of eligible PLHIV receiving ART2
SRHR.2.7. Number of people receiving interventions against TB, malaria, hepatitis and NTDs
SRHR.3 Better public and private health care for family planning, pregnancies and childbirth, including safe abortions
SRHR.3.1. Number of health workers trained in ANC and PNC, safe delivery and abortion care
SRHR.3.2. % of births attended by skilled health personnel
SRHR.3.3. Number of comprehensive safe (post-)abortion care services provided
SRHR.3.4. Number of initiatives to promote private sector involvement in SRH and HIV/AIDS services
SRHR.3.5. % coverage of the Minimum Initial Service Package, including basic emergency obstetric care (BeMOC)
SROL.1 Human Security: Reduced levels of violence and levels of fear experienced
SROL.1.1. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who report a reduction in violent incidents in the area where they live
SROL.1.10. Number of national/local authorities supported in addressing root causes and triggers of violent extremism, particularly through SRoL (push factors)
SROL.1.2. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who report they are feeling secure in the area where they live
SROL.1.3. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who report increased levels of trust in security sector actors
SROL.1.4. Number of beneficiaries who report having received positive service provision by formal and informal authorities with regard to human security
SROL.1.5. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who report that they have a more negative perception about violent extremist organisations
SROL.1.6. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) from marginalised groups who report on reduced levels of violence and fear experienced
SROL.1.7. Number of policy influencing initiatives aimed at long-term stabilisation

SROL.1.8. Number of beneficiaries with relevant knowledge and skills to support the formal security sector to strengthen reform processes that ensure increased accountability, transparency and gendersensitivity
SROL.1.9. Number of community-based security sector providers that have improved knowledge and skills to offer effective, accountable and responsive service to citizens and government
SROL.2 Rule of Law Strengthened: Citizens are better able to access their rights through fair, efficient, impartial, independent and accountable institutions
SROL.2.1. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) with access to justice [note: this is an official DGIS-indicator] (separate out: no. of women who present cases of sexual violence or domestic abuse)
SROL.2.2. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who have improved awareness of their rights and/or of how to address justice problems (claim, defend, and or recover rights)
SROL.2.3. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who access transitional justice mechanisms
SROL.2.4. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who have improved awareness of their rights
SROL.2.5. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) from marginalised groups who have improved access to their rights and judicial service facilities.
SROL.2.6. Number of beneficiaries with increased capacity to support policies that promote increase to access to justice

SROL.2.7. Number of beneficiaries with increased capacity to provide (policy) advice on specialised topics such as informal justice, commercial justice, rehabilitation, juvenile justice, sharia, gender issues
SROL.2.8. Number of justice innovations (e.g. scenario planning)
SROL.3 Peace processes & political governance: States, regional and local authorities and societies at large are able to effectively prevent and resolve conflict in a non-violent and inclusive manner
SROL.3.1. Number conflicts that are addressed and resolved by community structures by the programme (note: this is an ARC indicator)
SROL.3.2. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who feel that community grievances of targeted groups (e.g. women, youth or a specific ethnic group) are effectively addressed (note: this is an ARC indicator)
SROL.3.3. Participation (and satisfaction) in governance processes (political decision-making, mediation and dialogue) by representation of various groups, with special reference to women and youth
SROL.3.4. Perception on accountability/transparency of governance structures
SROL.3.5. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who feel represented by the government structures
SROL.3.6. Number of national and/or local level conflict resolution and peacebuilding mechanisms supported
SROL.3.7. Number of beneficiaries with increased knowledge and skills to support policy influencing of incountry and regional conflict resolution and peacebuilding interventions

SROL.3.8. Number of beneficiaries with increased knowledge and skills to support interventions at national level to increase civil society engagement and at local level to increase community engagement in political decision-making
SROL.3.9. Number of beneficiaries with improved capacity for policy influencing on aspects of political governance and state building
SROL.4 Social and economic reconstruction: Income generating and livelihoods opportunities to prevent the (re)occurrence of conflicts, instability or irregular migration
SROL.4.1. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who feel represented by the government structures
SROL.4.10. Number of people supported to improve their income/ livelihood opportunities
SROL.4.2. (disaggregated) Number of programme beneficiaries who started a business / self-employment activity and sustained it 6 months after they started

SROL.4.3. (disaggregated) Number of programme beneficiaries who indicate that their business / self-employment activities (which existed already before the grantees' interventions) have grown over the last 6 months
SROL.4.4. (disaggregated) Number of trained/supported programme beneficiaries who have become employed
SROL.4.5. (disaggregated) Number of direct jobs supported by targeted companies
SROL.4.6. (disaggregated) Number of communities in programme areas that have adopted and are implementing livelihood protection strategies
SROL.4.7. Number of people with improved income in fragile and conflict-affected states
SROL.4.8. Number of people using new or improved water points in fragile and conflict-affected states
SROL.4.9. Number of direct jobs supported
W.1 Water is used sustainably and equitably, ensuring the needs of all sectors and the environment
W.1.1. Number of river basin delta organisations supported on water management
W.1.2. Number of professionals trained in water management
W.1.3. Number of people benefitting from operational plans for integrated water resources management of basins
W.1.4. Areas of basins with an operational plan for integrated water resources management
W.1.5. Number of people supported for protection against floods
W.1.6. Number of people supported for improved irrigation and drainage
W.1.7. Number of people supported for improved watershed protection
W.1.8. Number of people supported for safe drinking water and adequate sanitary facilities
W.2 Water is used sustainably and equitably across national borders (i.e. transboundary water management)
W.2.1. Number of institutions able to carry out their duties with respect to transboundary water management
W.2.2. Number of professionals trained in transboundary water management
W.2.3. Number of plans for integrated climate resilient water resources management of transboundary water river basins
W.2.4. Areas of transboundary basins with an operational arrangement for water cooperation
W.2.5. Number of people benefitting (indirectly) from operational arrangements for water cooperation in transboundary basins
W.2.6. Number of people (indirectly) benefitting from transboundary water management projects
W.3 Water efficiency in agriculture increased
W.3.1. Number of institutions indirectly benefitting from innovative and efficient water allocation methodologies which increase crop yield

W.3.2. Number of associations, water users organisations and number of their professionals indirectly trained in applications in water-efficiency ranging from crop selection to irrigation scheduling etc
W.3.3. Number of institutions that use the FAO AQUASTAT database to measure water productivity
W.3.4. Number of 'ready-to-use' applications for farmers and policy officers are developed and distributed
W.3.5. Number of farmers with a higher yield with the same amount of used water
W.4 People use safe drinking water and adequate sanitary facilities
W.4.1. Number of people trained in WASH
W.4.2. Number of WASH organisations indirectly strengthened
W.4.3. Number of climate resilient drinking water points constructed
W.4.4. Number of climate resilient sanitary facilities constructed
W.4.5. Number of students / pupils benefitting from improved drinking water and sanitary facilities in schools
W.4.6. Number of health centres with improved drinking water and sanitary facilities
